channel.title: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
channel.description:
This is probably never going to happen, which is why I labeled it a pointless thread, but nevertheless fun to think about.
Words like Colonel are impossible to read as "kernel" without being told that it's pronounced like that because the english language isn't phonetic.
Should the english language remove unnecessary letters, such as c and q, and replace them with k's, and such, and become a phonetic language?
examples: cat ---> kat suck ---> suk sex ---> seks

item.title: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
item.dc:creator: Eric_Fong
item.description:
“seks” is melayu version of “sex”

item.title: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
item.dc:creator: Soup
item.description:
Lol, people though that England etc weren’t countries? Massive fail.

Also, I don’t really care if the English language doesn’t always make sense. If you’re going to bitch about languages not making sense, use one of those universal languages instead.

Read full topic

item.description:
That’s what shits me off about the British Isles. What exactly do you people call yourselves?

I just call Northern Ireland and England Britain, and everything else by their normal names. Screw this UK nonsense.

item.title: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
item.dc:creator: Door
item.description:
For me it’s:

Wikipedia:

Parliamentary democracy,
Constitutional monarchy,
Unitary state

Even then, each ‘country’ within the Kingdom has it’s own national identity and government(each with differing amounts of power).

We should stop getting off topic so much though. @___@

Read full topic

item.title: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
item.dc:creator: Door
item.description:
Jingles:

If we made every single language welsh we would have no need for vowels (joke)

a e i o u - English vowels.
a e i o u w y - Welsh vowels.
Welsh has more vowels than English, so that joke really isn’t funny or humorous in any way.

Jingles:

I was reffering to England when I said our.

There’s more than one country in the United Kingdom that speak English… don’t forget Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.

Read full topic
item.source: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language

item.title: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
item.dc:creator: Siggs
item.description:
To backtrack again…

Hazzmat:

Lol you’re British and you don’t even know how to spell that word in your own language? It’s metre. Englishmen say metre, Americans say meter.

:brow: I’ve always said meter…regardless, try not to sound so high and mighty next time, it just makes you sound like an arse imho

Read full topic
item.source: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language

item.source: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language

item.title: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
item.dc:creator: Marb
item.description:
Just to backtrack a bit…

Hazzmat:

Englishmen say metre, Americans say meter.

Aside from any accent, are you saying there really is a difference between pronouncing meter and metre? Because as far as I know, I’ve never heard an Englishman pronounce it “mee-treh” or any other way for that matter.

But more on topic, I’ve always thought the English alphabet was terribly inefficient (at least the Americanized version)… but, I guess that’s what you get when a country is born of many different nationalities and borrows from many different languages. It changes over time to suit it’s own needs, but I’ll be honest, things like “bouquet” changing to “bokay” is just laziness, imho. (ok, so bokay is far from “official,” but I’ve been seeing it for years and it ticks me off for some reason)

Read full topic
item.source: Pointless Threads: Changing the English Language
